Merge Sort

Divide in half, sort each half, merge them

Split a deck of cards in half, sort each half separately, then merge them by always picking the smaller top card from each pile.

How It Works

  1. Divide array into two halves
  2. Recursively sort left half
  3. Recursively sort right half
  4. Merge the two sorted halves

Complexity

  • Time Best: O(n log n)
  • Time Avg: O(n log n)
  • Time Worst: O(n log n)
  • Space: O(n) - needs extra array

When to Use

  • Guaranteed O(n log n) needed
  • Linked lists (no random access needed)
  • External sorting (large files)
  • Stable sort needed

Quicksort

Pick a pivot, put smaller left, larger right, repeat

Choose one person as the 'pivot'. Everyone shorter goes left, everyone taller goes right. Now repeat for each group.

How It Works

  1. Pick a pivot element (often last element)
  2. Partition: move smaller elements left, larger right
  3. Pivot is now in its final position
  4. Recursively sort left and right partitions

Complexity

  • Time Best: O(n log n)
  • Time Avg: O(n log n)
  • Time Worst: O(nÂ²) - rare with good pivot
  • Space: O(log n) - recursion stack

When to Use

  • General-purpose sorting
  • Average case matters most
  • In-place sorting needed
  • Cache efficiency important
